loans.name: Shahida

texts.en: Shahida  is 51 years old married woman. She is shown in the photo with her son who is running a small shop successfully for many years where he sell various items such as calling cards, mobile accessories, chargers, etc. For the improvement of her son's business, Shahida  has applied for a loan of 40000 PKR  to purchase more items such as calling cards, memory cards, and mobile batteries. With the help of this loan, he can meet the increasing demands of his clients and generate more revenue. She is positive that his son's future earnings will increase.

loans.use: to purchase more items such as calling cards, memory cards, and mobile batteries

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en: Margaret is 56 years old, married and all her children are independent. Unfortunately, one of her daughters passed away and left three children. Margaret takes care of the three children. Two are in primary school while the oldest one assists her to run the business. She is working hard to educate them up to at least college level. She set her business near the busiest bus stage of Rongai. Her business is located near the bus stop and therefore makes a lot of sales in the evening when the residents going back home from work. However, in the morning she supplies to those who roast\boil maize along the roadside. She buys fresh maize from various markets; Wakulima, Kiserian and Kadisi.

loans.use: Margaret wants to start selling other food stuffs such as yellow bananas, mangoes, green pepper, and onions.

loans.name: Luis

texts.en:
Luis sells cleaning products for the home. He started his business selling these products door to door. He launched his business selling polish, sponges and clothespins. He continues to sell those products along with cleaning clothes and aluminum cleaner.

Luis would use the loan to buy products wholesale in order to earn more profit. He aspires to one day be a distributor so he could help and give work to other people. He has faith that with additional merchandise in stock his business will grow. Luis is the father of 2 children. He is 37 years old and married. Luis has hope that with this loan he'll improve his family's quality of life and bring stability and growth to his business.

Translated by Erin Corcoran, Kiva volunteer.

Luis vende productos de limpieza para el hogar. Luis empezó su negocio vendiendo estos productos puerta a puerta. Se inicio vendiendo lustre, esponja, pinza. Ahora el continua vendiendo este mismo producto junto con toallas de limpieza y aluminio blanqueador. Luis usara el préstamo para invertir comprando estos productos al por mayor y así obtener mejores ingresos. El tiene la aspiración de llegar a tener una distribuidora, de esta manera poder ayudar y dar empleo a otras personas. El tiene la fe que teniendo mas mercadería en stock su negocio crecerá. Luis es Padre de dos hijos, esta casado, tiene 37 años. Luis tiene la esperanza que con este préstamo mejorara la calidad de vida de su familia y le dará estabilidad y crecimiento al negocio.

loans.use: Invest in cleaning products

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: I will use the money to diversify and expand my business.

texts.en: Mrs. H. is 22 years old, and her husband is 27 years old. They have a 1 year old son. While her husband makes and installs iron frames for windows, she runs a rice cracker bakery. They live in Nghe An, a rural province in the upper center of Vietnam. The bakery has been a family business for over ten years now, and her profit is $3.00 per day. She wants a loan to pay the supplier of rice and sesame promptly, instead of buying on credit with very high interest rates.

loans.use: To buy more rice and sesame for her business

loans.name: Sorie

texts.en: Sorie T. is a petty trader who owns a shop in Fadugu village in Sierra Leone.  He is the chairman of the Traders Union for the entire chiefdom. Sorie is married with five children.  Originally, Sorie operated his business as a partnership with two colleagues.  With his previous loan, Sorie decided to separate from the partners and started his own grocery business.  He is now requesting a loan of $350 to expand it.  Sorie said that he used the profit from the previous loan to put up the small kiosk for the business and needs more loan capital to increase the stock.

loans.use: Growth of his grocery business

loans.name: Koleti

texts.en:
Koleti loves planting and eating vegetables, which is why she is interested in running a vegetable garden business. She is 36-years-old, a mother of three kids, and is separated from her husband.

She started off with a loan of $300 USD, which was spent on buying chemicals for garden maintenance, as well as vegetable seeds for planting her crops. She works really hard, because this is her only source of income for her family needs, especially her children's school fees. Even though she feels exhausted sometimes, she remains strong. She knows that her family needs her. She is very happy for the financial support from SPBD’s loan program.

loans.use: To buy vegetable seeds and chemicals needed for her vegetable garden.

loans.name: Zuberi

texts.en: Zuberi is a 44-year-old father of three and a resident of Bombom in Dar es Salaam. He runs a pharmacy, a business he has been doing for six years. He sells all sorts of common medicines for fever, malaria and other common diseases for women and children. He is in need of $725 to help him expand the stock in his pharmacy.

loans.use: To expand his business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Invest in new equipment and improve the appearance of her store

loans.name: Kalungi E Group

texts.en:
This group has been together for seven months. Leontina has a clothes selling business. She wants to use the extra business profits to increase capital by stocking more clothes. Annet makes and sells snacks and wants to use the loan to expand business. Edith has a public pay phone. Rebecca sells envelopes.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes for sale.

loans.name: Barbara

texts.es:
Mrs. Barbara belongs to the Bellavista Communal Bank, located at 367 Jr. Roca Fuerte Avenue, in the district of Calleria, the state of Ucayali. Barbara is 42 years old, she is the mother of 4 children and is separated. The first loan that she received from Manuela Ramos of 300 soles she decided to invest in the sale of food. Nowadays she continues selling food, which has grown in earnings and it is due to the rich maturity that her food has. Barbara wakes up very early to go to the market, later in the mornings she dedicates herself to the preparation of her foods and at night, with the help of her children, she leaves to sell her product. With the loan of 1700 soles, which she will repay in 5 months, she will buy plates, forks, tables, seats, tablecloths and the rest of the capital she will designate to the daily purchase of the supplies. Barbara has a rough routine everyday, but without it she couldn’t take care of her family life. She has always had the thought in her mind to better her business with the sale of food and she hopes to continue this with the support of Manuela Ramos.

Translated from Spanish by Fallon Shields, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Bárbara pertenece al banco comunal Bellavista, ubicado en el Jr. Roca Fuerte N° 367, distrito de Calleria, departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 42 años, es madre de 4 hijos y es separada. Con el primer préstamo que recibió de Manuela Ramos de S/ 300 decide invertir en la venta de comida. En la actualidad continua con la venta de comida, la cual ha crecido en ganancias y ello debido a la rica sazón que tiene. Barbara se levanta muy temprano para ir al mercado, luego en las mañanas se dedica a la preparación de sus comidas y por las noches, con la ayuda de sus hijos, sale a vender su producto. Con el préstamo de S/.1,700, el cual pagará en 5 meses, comprará platos, tenedores, mesas, sillas, manteles y el resto de capital lo destinó para la compra diaria de los víveres. Bárbara tiene una rutina muy agitada todos los días, pero aún así no descuida su vida familiar. Siempre tiene en mente ampliar su negocio con la venta de comidas y espera seguir contando con el apoyo de Manuela Ramos.

loans.use: To purchase plates, forks, tables, seats, etc.

loans.name: Ruth

texts.es:
Ruth L. and her daughter live in their own home in the Alto Sopocachi zone of La Paz. Ruth is employed and works as a secretary for a public transit company in the city. Her home has one bedroom in her home that is roughly constructed (simply brick walls with a metal roof). Ruth would like to complete this room so that it can become her daughter’s room. Her daughter is getting older and up till now still sleeps in the same room as her mother, Ruth.

The loan will be used to do the finish work on the room. This is the first time that Ruth has requested a loan and the socioeconomic analysis shows her to be a good candidate. She is approved for the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Casey Unrein, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Ruth L. vive en casa propia en la zona de Alto Sopocachi de la Ciudad de La Paz con su hija. La señora Ruth es empleada, trabaja como secretaria en una empresa de transporte publico de esta ciudad. Su vivienda tiene una habitación que se encuentra en obra gruesa (construcción de muros de ladrillo y techo de calamina), la misma que la señora Ruth quiere concluir para que sea el dormitorio de su hija que ya esta alcanzando a la mayoría de edad y que aun se encuentra ocupando la misma habitación con su madre. El crédito solicitado será destinado a la construcción en obra fina de una habitación. Esta es la primera ocasión que solicita un préstamo y el análisis socioeconómico realizado la califica favorablemente y puede acceder a un crédito.

loans.use: Complete the construction of a room so that her daughter can have a room to herself.

loans.name: Sawudatu

texts.en:
Sawudatu M. prepares food for sale. She is married and has 4 children. Business is doing very well, and customers are increasing.

She is asking for $525 as additional capital to buy more food stuffs to increase production.

loans.use: As additional capital to buy more food stuffs to increase production

loans.name: Ngoc Thanh

texts.vi:
Ms. D. Ngoc Thanh is twenty six year old. Her family has a computer repair store and an internet business. Her husband does the repair works while she takes care of the accounting and administration. Her group already participated once in the 6 month loan program and they all repaid very well. This time she requests a loan of $VN2.242.000 to buy more equipments for her store.

Ms. D. thi Nga requests a loan of $VN 2.242.000 to start a business in cutlery.

Ms. Nguyen thi Tam requests a loan of $VN 2.242.000 to start a snack food business.

Ms. Le thi Quy requests a loan of $VN 2.242.000 to buy rice to make rice pastry for sales.

Ms Nguyen thi Ngoan requests a loan of $VN 2.242.000 to have capital for a breakfast food business..

Ms. Nguyen thi Hoa requests a loan of $VN 2.006.000 to start a retail store. .

Translated from Vietnamese by Hien, a Kiva volunteer

Chị Đăng Ngọc Thanh (MS:030005), năm nay 26 tuổi. Gia đinh chị có có cửa hàng kinh doanh Internet và sửa chữa máy tính. Chị trực tiếp đứng ra trông quán và thu tiền, chồng chị phụ trách việc sửa chữa máy tính. Nhóm chị đều đã trải qua một chu kỳ vay 6 tháng và đã hoàn trả rất tốt. Lần này chị vay 2.242.000 VND để mua linh kiện thay thế cho máy tính ở của hàng Internet. Chị Đặng Thị Nga (MS: 030001), vay 2.242.000 VND để mua hàng dao kéo về bán. Chị Nguyễn Thị Tâm (MS: 030002), vay 2.242.000 VND để mua đỗ nấu chè bán. Chị Lê Thị Quý (MS: 030003), vay 2.242.000 VND mua gạo làm bánh cuốn bán. Chị Nguyễn Thị Ngoan (MS: 030004), vay 2.242.000 VND để thêm vốn bán hàng ăn sáng. Chị Nguyễn Thi Hòa (MS: 030035), vay 2.006.000 VND để mua hàng tạp hóa về bán.

loans.use: Business

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.es:
Yolanda is married and has 5 children; 3 women and 2 man who are married, her husband is retired. She started her business to help her husband support their children and pay for their studies. She started the business 7 years ago selling different items and has been selling catalog cosmetics for approximately 3 years.

Following her friend's advice, she started offering them among her friends and acquaintances, who then recommended her products to other people and that's how she started building a client base.

She needs a loan of $550 USD that she will pay back in 6 months to buy merchandise and give better service to her clients by having the products ready in the moment they are needed. With your support Yolanda will make her business grow.

Translated from Spanish by Sofia Burt, Kiva Volunteer.

Yolanda esta casada, es casada y si tiene 5 hijos de los cuales 3 son mujeres y 2 hombres ya casados, su esposo es jubilado. Inició el negocio para ayudar a su esposo en la manutencion de sus hijos y pagar sus estudios. Comenzó el negocio hace 7 años vendiendo diferentes articulos y lleva aproximadamente 3 años vendiendo cosmeticos por catalogo.

Por consejo de una amiga, empezo a ofrecerlos entre sus amistades y conocidos, quienes la empezaron a recomendar a otras personas y asi fue creando su cartera de clientes.

Ella necesita un prestamo por US $550 que pagara en 6 meses para comprar mercancia y darle mejor servicio a sus clientes, contando con los productos en el momento que se lo soliciten. Con tu apoyo Yolanda hara crecer su negocio.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise

loans.name: Flor De María

texts.es:
Flor de Maria dedicates her time to agriculture and farming. She raises cows and bulls, which also help with her crops. On weekends, Flor de Maria sells milk in the markets of the nearest city. She is a mother of three studious children, and she hopes to provide them with everything necessary for their studies. For these reasons, Flor de Maria would like a loan of 2000 soles, which she'll use to buy another cow, thereby enabling her to sell milk and cheese more frequently. With part of the money, Flor de Maria would also like to help her husband, who is also a farmer, by purchasing seeds and fertilizer. Flor de Maria hopes that you'll accept her request.

Translated from Spanish by Sarah Bishop, Kiva Volunteer.

Flor de María es una mujer dedicada a la agricultura y ganadería, cría toros y vacas, los que también le ayudan en el trabajo agrícola. Durante los fines de semana, vende leche en los mercados de la ciudad más cercana. Es madre de 3 niños quienes son escolares y desea brindarles todo lo necesario para sus estudios. Es por estas razones, nos comenta, requiere de 2000 soles que le servirá en la compra de una vaca más, además de vender leche y queso con más frecuencia, también le gustaría, con parte del dinero, apoyar a su esposo que es agricultor, con la compra de semillas y abono.Flor de María queda a la espera de la aceptación de su pedido.

loans.use: Purchase of a cow to sell milk and cheese, as well as seeds and fertilizer.

loans.name: Musarat's Group

texts.en:
Musarat baji is the wife of M. and the mother of four children: two sons and two daughters. She owns a two-room brick house and has been living in it for the last 40 years. She lives in a small city named Chichawatni, Pakistan. Her elder son has a grocery shop and the young one makes embroidered dresses. Her elder daughter is in 8th standard and the younger is in 5th standard. Her husband runs a grocery shop. Musarat baji successfully completed repaying two loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute in Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy groceries for her husband and her son's grocery stores.

She is joined in her loan group by several more members. Ghulam Fatima baji wants a loan to buy crockery to re-sell. Bashiran baji wants a loan to repair her family's auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled vehicle). Zubaida baji wants a loan to buy wooden baskets to re-sell. Sajida baji wants a loan to buy shoes for her shoe selling business. Mumtaz baji wants a loan to buy a lathe machine.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy groceries for grocery shops

loans.name: Prak

texts.en: Mrs. Prak N. owns a small grocery store in the local market which is located in Kampong Chrey Village in Takeo Province. Aside from this business, she is a farmer who faces an obstacle because the soil in her field is infertile. To solve this problem, Mrs. Prak N. decided to ask for a loan to purchase fertilizer. Her husband, Mr. Cheang Mok, is a construction worker who earns $2.50 per day, a very small income to support his household. Mrs. Prak N. is 46 years old and the mother of a child who helps her in both the plantation and the grocery business. Her husband is on the left in the photo.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer

loans.name: Khady

texts.fr: Khady F., 48 ans, mariée avec 06 enfants en charge est membre du banc villageois de Pout Diack depuis 6 ans. Elle veut acheter des tissus et du fil pour confectionner et vendre des robes et des draps de lit et renforcer aussi son activité d’élevage. Son souhait est d’accroître ses revenus pour financer une boutique céréalière. <b> Le prêt qu’elle sollicite sera remboursé au bout de six mois en une seule échéance. <b/>
texts.en:
Khady F., age 48, is married and has six children in her care. She has been a member of the village loan group of Pout Diack for six years. She wants to buy fabrics and thread to make and sell dresses and bedsheets and also to boost her livestock-raising business. Her wish is to increase her income to finance a shop for selling grain. The loan she is requesting will be repaid all at once at the end of six months.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cloth, thread, steers, and cattle feed

loans.name: Gladis Guido  Ruiz Group

texts.es:
Los miembros del g/s LOS SANTOS viven en la periferia del barrio monimbo de Masaya a unas 10 cuadras de la sucursal de adim. Por vivir en la ciudad les ha permitido tener aprobado sus estudios primarios, por tal motivo son bien expresivas y de trato muy amable.
Con mucho esfuerzo y dedicación han logrado mantener su negocio, manifiestan que con la ayuda de adim han mejorado las condiciones de su vivienda, negocio y de su familia, en la actualidad están en su octavo ciclo.
 Doña Gladis es la coordinadora del g/s,  desde pequeña ayudaba a su mama en la preparación de refrescos lo que le sirvió para ahora ella tener su propio negocio, han tenido  8 créditos con adim, los cuales le han ayudado ya que compro una mantenedora para la conservación de los refrescos y además  vende hielo y gaseosas.  Este g/s ha participado en los talleres que desarrollo empresarial ha impartido,  el éxito de este g/s es la comunicación y solidaridad que ellas mantienen.
Dicen estar agradecida por que adim además de crédito las ha capacitado, lo que han aprovechado para el manejo exitoso de sus negocios
texts.en:
The members of g/s LOS SANTOS live in the periphery of the minumbo neighborhood of Masaya, ten blocks from the adim office. Because they live in the city they've been able to complete primary school, so they are expressive and nice. With a lot of effort and dedication they've achieved the creation of their businesses. With the help of adim they have been able to improve their living conditions, businesses, and family. They're now in their eighth loan cycle. Mrs. Gladis is the g/s coordinator. When Gladis was a young girl she helped her mother prepare refreshments. She now has her own business and has had eight loans with admin. These loans have helped her buy a fridge to preserve the refreshments, and she also sells ice and sodas. This g/s has participated in business development workshops, and it's success is in the communication and solidarity that the members maintain. They say that they are grateful for admin and the loans and training, which has enabled them to successfully manage their businesses.

Translated from Spanish by Sarah Bishop, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital to offer a greater variety of products to their clients

loans.name: Soun

texts.en: Soun R., 26, is married and lives together with her husband, their three children, and old mother (pictured in the photo) in the Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She works at a garment factory, earning around US$4 a day, while her husband owns a motor-taxi business, making a daily profit of US$4. Soun R. now needs a loan of US$800 to open a new business. She will use this money to purchase music equipment to rent out to the villagers whenever they have a party or wedding.

loans.use: Purchase of music equipment

loans.name: Xiomara Isabel

texts.es:
La Señora Xiomara Isabel B. Díaz tiene la edad de 46 años, su estado civil es casada, Doña Xiomara tiene 2 hijos de los cuales sus edades son las siguientes su hijo de 16 años de edad cursa recientemente el 4 año de secundaria u su hijo menor de 9 años cursa el 4 grado de primaria, su compañero de vida labora contador de la empresa de Enacal, sus propósitos son de obtener los ingresos necesarios de su inversión por lo que la situación en la que nos encontramos es muy difícil y el único medio de ayuda  que presentamos actualmente en el país son las micro financieras y las organizaciones en el exterior que nos tienden la mano sus deseos son de tratar de salir adelante cada día para mejorar su situación económica y sus sueños son de engrandecer su negocio para asegurar el prometedor fututo de estudios de sus hijos.


La actividad económica es la de mercadería en general en la que expande los productos como: topa interior, bisuterías, zapatos y sandalias, la ubicación de su negocio es de forma ambulante, el tiempo que tiene de poseer su negocio es de 3 años, sus inicios se dan por cuenta propia por lo que tenia que luchar por sus propósitos y es así como empieza este negocio con pocos productos y empezó a distribuir su producto por lo que no tuvo resultado ya que mucha gente no le pago la mercadería por lo que mas tarde decide invertir solo en ropa y empieza a dividir a su mejores clientes para realizar la distribución de sus productos y es así como obtiene su negocio, el financiamiento es para capital de trabajo por lo que tiene que efectuar la compra de oro laminado en Managua y ropa de varón y también están los diferentes lugares de León  donde le venden de forma favorable para sus productos y agradece a Fundación y las organizaciones amigas para que se pueda realizar el financiamiento.
texts.en:
Xiomara Isabel B. D. is 46 years old and married. Xiomara has two children, of the following ages: Her 16 year old son recently finished his fourth year of high school; her younger son, nine years old, finished fourth grade. Her husband is an accountant for the Enacal business. Her goal is to secure the necessary income for her investment (in her business) because the situation that we find ourselves in is very difficult, and the only form of help that now presents itself in this country are the microfinance institutions and the outside organizations that hold out their hands to us. Xiomara wants to try to advance each day so that she can improve her economic situation. Her dream is to grow her business to ensure her children will be able to continue their studies. Xiomara's business is a general store in which are sold products such as: clothing, costume jewelry, shoes, and sandals. Her business is mobile. She has had her business for three years, which began with her own idea that she had to fight for. Because of this she began this business with few products and began to distribute her product but it didn't have (good) results. Not enough people (customers) paid for (bought) the merchandise, so later she decided to invest only in clothes and began to cater to her better customers to distribute her products. This loan is for operating expenses because she has to buy gold-plated (items) in Managua and men's clothing is in different places in Leon where they are sold in a favorable way. Xiomara is grateful to the Foundation and its partner organizations that are helping her get this loan.

Translated from Spanish by Olivia Engkvist, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Operating expenses

loans.name: Amelia

texts.es:
Amelia es socia del Bancomunal Las Orquídeas 
Amelia es casada, tiene 45 años,  tres hijos D. 23,18 y 13 los mayores estudian  educación superior  y él ultima esta en la escuela. 
Amelia trabaja desD. hace cuatro años  D. lunes a viernes por  las mañanas en el cafetín D. una empresa dando desayuno, ella lleva todo preparado se levanta a las cuatro D. la mañana para preparar 120 samwish  D.  queso,  huevo, palta, jamón, triples, empanadas, kekes, tiene una persona que le ayuda y por las tardes  venD. productos D. belleza por catalogo.

DesD. que esta en Finca, su capital ha crecido y ha podido comprar muchas cosas para su casa y negocio, al principio vendía 30 panes, ahora pueD. invertir mas, otra D. las cosas que aprendió es a ser puntual en sus pagos, a ahorrar y ser solidarias con las personas.    
Necesita 1600 soles, para comprar los víveres, para la preparar los sandwich, también  necesita comprar una  sanwichera y una licuadora. 
El sueño D. Amelia es trabajar por las tardes en otro cafetín y  que sus hijos terminen su carrera.
texts.en:
Amelia is a member of the Las Orquídeas community bank. She is married, 45 years old and has three children aged 23, 18 and 13. Her two eldest children are in university and her youngest is in school. Amelia has been working for the past four years in the cafeteria of a company making breakfast from Monday to Friday in the mornings. She brings everything already prepared. She is up at 4 A.M. and with a helper she makes 120 sandwiches with cheese, eggs, avocado, ham, triple sandwiches (layered sandwiches), empanadas, cakes. In the afternoons she sells beauty products from a catalogue. Since joining Finca, her capital has grown and she has been able to buy many things for her home and her business. Initially she sold 30 loaves but she has been able to invest more. Another thing she has learnt is to be punctual with her repayments, to save and to support others. She needs 1,600 soles to buy the ingredients to make the sandwiches. She also needs to buy a sandwich press and a blender. Amelia's dream is to work afternoons in another cafeteria and that her children finish their studies.

Translated from Spanish by Laure Kwon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy the ingredients to make layered sandwiches, as well as sandwich press and a blender.

loans.name: Sheyla

texts.es: Sheyla tiene 26 años y vive  con su pareja en una casa arrendada. Ella trabaja elaborando diseños a computadora para avisos publicitarios en su negocio, los cuales elabora al gusto de sus clientes, quienes cada vez son más. Ella se preparó estudiando los programas de computadora utilizados para el diseño gráfico y poder realizar ese tipo de trabajos que incluyen mucha creatividad y novedad. El gran sueño de Sheyla es ser una de las mejores diseñadoras gráficas de su zona y también invertir en nuevas oportunidades para su negocio, es decir incursionar en otro tipo de negocios como en la venta de otros productos, como comestibles y venderlos a sus vecinos y amistades para generase mayores ingresos. Es la primera oportunidad de Sheyla en solicitar un préstamo dentro de MFP, y asume un compromiso de ser una de las integrantes más activas y responsables de su grupo. Es dinero que requiere es para invertir en la compra de mercadería para su nuevo negocio, así como en capacitarse en un curso rápido de diseño gráfico que será cubierto por el monto que ella está solicitando.
texts.en:
Sheyla is 26 years old and lives with her partner in a rented house. She works to create graphic design's used for advertising in her business, which she develops based on the tastes of her customers who are increasing. She studied the computer software used for graphic design, so she could accomplish this type of work that includes a lot of creativity and innovation. Sheyla’s great dream is to be one of the best graphic designers in her area and invest in new business opportunities. She would like to venture into other businesses such as selling other products such as groceries by selling them to neighbors and friends and generating more income. This is Sheyla’s first opportunity to apply for a loan with MFP, and she is committed to being one of the most active and responsible members of her group. The money she requests is to invest in buying merchandise for her new business, as well as to take another training course in graphic design.

Translated from Spanish by Jennie Campos, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Pay for a course to improve her business and invest in a new one

loans.name: Elise

texts.fr:
Née en 1968 à Porto-Novo,Capitale Administrative du Bénin, O. Elise réside dans le 4e arrondissement de la ville de Porto-Novo. Elise est mariée et mère de quatre enfants dont deux scolarisés. Elise Transforme de maïs en pâte localement appelée « MAWE », une activité qui lui permet de faire face aux charges familiales. Pour diversifier ses sources de revenu, Elise mène comme activité secondaire la vente d’huile de palme qu’elle distribue à ses clients à domicile. Bien qu’elle mène quotidiennement cette activité elle . Elise ne dispose pas d'assez de fonds pour rentabiliser ses activités et se faire plus de revenus à la hauteur de ses charges familiales. C'est pourquoi Elise sollicite un crédit pour renforcer ses activités. 

 
La signification de ALIDé en langue locale du Bénin, le Fon, est « un chemin existe toujours pour les plus pauvres ». Le Bénin est un petit pays de l’Afrique de l’Ouest à coté du Nigeria où le PIB par habitant est à $1,500. ALIDé offre les prêts spéciaux de 0% d’intérêt aux personnes très vulnérables et elle est dans un groupe qui lance bientôt un programme de la micro-assurance santé pour les bénéficiaires de micro crédit.
texts.en:
Born in 1968 in Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Bénin, Ms. O. Elise resides in the 4th district of Porto-Novo. She is married and the mother of four children, of whom two are in school. She takes corn and makes it into pâte, which is locally called "mawe" (cornmeal mash). This work enables her to cope with family expenses.

To diversify her sources of income, she runs a secondary business selling palm oil, which she distributes to customers in their homes. Although she works every day, she doesn't have enough funds for making her businesses profitable and for earning more to meet her family responsibilities. This is why she's requesting a loan for bolstering her businesses.

Alidé means “there is always a path for the poorest” in Benin’s local language of Fon. Benin is a small West African country located next to Nigeria and has a per capita GDP of $1,500. Alidé offers special loans to highly vulnerable people at an interest rate of 0%. It is part of a group that is soon launching a micro health insurance program for recipients of micro-loans.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sacks of corn

loans.name: Marietta

texts.en: A simple woman is Mrs. Marietta Buburan, 54 years old, married and a resident of Aloran, Misamis Occidental. Her husband is a photographer, and that’s why they decided to open up a photo studio, which is also the family’s primary source of income. Mrs. Buburan works as the cashier at the studio. At first, they started only with one or two film rolls used for taking pictures. Later, they expanded their business and opened a photo shop. Their customers are mostly students, private and public employees and the like. Being a member of Paglaum MPC, financial incapacity has never been a hindrance for the Baburan family. PMPC has helped them through the years. Today, she applies for PHP 14,900 to buy films and additional capital for recopying of photos. She is looking forward to having a successful and profitable business ahead.

loans.use: to buy films and payment for recopying of photos

loans.name: Musharraf

texts.en:
N. Musharraf is 26 years old. She is the loving wife and mother of two kids. For four years Musharraf has been running a store which she rents. She has been selling different kinds of paints and other tools necessary for house repairing. Over these years Musharraf has acquired the knowledge and skills required for her business. Since Musharraf started her store, she has been able to increase her clientele and in order to provide them with a good service, she is requesting a loan of 4000 Somoni, which she will use to buy merchandise to increase her assortment of inventory.    

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes being a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Increasing the range of goods for sale

loans.name: Julia

texts.es:
Julia  es socia del Bancomunal Juan Pablo II
Julia es casada tiene cinco hijos, todos mayores y ya están casados.
Julia vendió por ocho años en el mercado en un puesto lencería, medias, pero decidió poner en su casa una pequeña bodega  bazar donde vende cosméticos y lencería.
Julia necesita un préstamo de 3400 soles, para la compra de cerveza  y una exhibidora de gaseosas.
Desde que está en Finca, aprendió ahorrar por el sistema de ahorros que tiene finca, también aprendió  a ser puntual. 
El sueño de Julia es ser mayorista de cerveza y gaseosa.
texts.en:
Julia is a member of the Juan Pablo II cooperative bank Julia is married and has five children, all grown and married. Julia sold items such as undergarments and socks from a stall in the market for eight years, but then decided to open a store in her house where she sells cosmetics and undergarments. Julia needs a loan of 3400 soles to buy beer and a soft drink display case. Since she started with Finca, she has learned how to save through their system. She also learned how to be punctual. Julia’s dream is to be a wholesaler of beer and soda.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Julia needs a loan of 3400 soles, to buy beer and a soft drink display case.

loans.name: Sarvar

texts.ru: Сарвару 31 год, женат имеет 2 детей. Постоянной работы не имеет и поэтому несколько лет назад он стал работать у одного мастера и обучаться профессии мастера отделочника. Прошло несколько лет и Сарвар стал заниматься отделкой квартир и домов самостоятельно. Сейчас у него есть 2 ученика с которыми он берет заказы и занимается отделкой домов и частных квартир. Когда он получает заказ, то покупает строительные материалы. После окончания работ он получает оплату и на эти доходы кормит свою семью. Сейчас он подал заявку на займ КИВА и собирается приобрести краски и цемент для продолжения своих работ.
texts.en:
Sarvar is 31 years old, married and has two children. Because he does not have a permanent job, he started his master decorator apprenticeship several years ago. Few years passed, and Sarvar became involved in decorating apartments and houses on his own. He currently has two apprentices, who help him complete orders decorating houses and apartments. When he receives an order, Sarvar buys building materials. He gets paid once work is completed and uses this income to support his family. Sarvar requested this loan from Kiva and plans to buy paint and cement needing to continue his work.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of building materials

loans.name: Paulina

texts.en:
Paulina H. sells charcoal and is requesting a loan to expand the business by purchasing more charcoal. Paulina is 40 years old and married. Her husband is a driver. They have two children, who are both attending school. With the extra profits generated from her loan, she hopes to pay her children's school fees.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To increase her inventory of charcoal to sell.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose Y. is fifty years old, widowed, and has given birth to four children, all of whom are still in school. She lives with her children in a rented apartment in a busy commercial town called Suhum in the Eastern Region of Ghana.

Rose works hard to be able to provide for her family. She runs a provision store in her community selling provisions such as sugar, candies, bread, etc. Her store is by the roadside.

Rose has been in business for fifteen years and wants a loan to buy provisions in bulk to increase her stock. Rose aspires to sponsor all her children in school to the higher levels.

loans.use: To buy provisions in bulk to increase her stock

loans.name: Maria Diega

texts.en:
Maria Diega is from the village of Balintawak, Aurora, Zamboanga Del Sur. To make a living, Maria operates a flower garden where she grows flowers for sale in the retail sector. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business, comes from selling flowers to local community members. Maria has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Maria joined PMPC to gain access to financial to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Maria has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 from PMPC. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business. Maria is requesting a new loan of 30,000 which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Maria from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: expansion of flower garden

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en:
Juliet and her family are living in the rural community of Barangay Parabba Peñablanca, Cagayan. She is married to Edwin S., a house carpenter in their community. Her husband used to earn a labor fee of 350 PHP a day. They have seven children with ages ranging from 13 to 25 years old. Despite the hardships of life, Juliet is happy to have her family bonded and cooperative.

For her general store business, Juliet is requesting additional business capital of around 22,000 PHP from Kiva lenders in order to develop her business to support her children's education. They will make her proud someday if they are able to pursue and finish college. Furthermore, Juliet dreams of developing her business into a grocery store someday, a goal for which, according to her, patience and hard work will be the key. In the meantime, Juliet is going to buy additional supplies of items such as sugar, coffee, mild detergent, fragrance soap, 10 cases of soft drinks, canned goods, sacks of sugar, etc., to retail in her store using the loan she is requesting from Kiva. She hopes to gain lenders' support in order to improve her living conditions.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Delia

texts.en:
Delia M. aims to give her family a progressive living with the support of her husband Juanito.  They are living in Almaguer South, Bambang, Nueva Vizcaya. Despite the hardships of life, the couple helps each other earn and save for the future of their children. 

Her hog raising business is being maintained well. Her ambition to further improve the business into a bigger one motivated Delia to sekk for financial assistance from Kiva lenders amounting to PHP10, 000 as additional working capital. Through her hog raising, Delia is able to help her husband financially in their farming which is their major source of income and also enable her to provide the educational needs of her children.  She hope that her business will grow and become successful with the continuous support of Kiva and by working hard.

loans.use: additional capital

loans.name: Anita

texts.en:
Anita A. is a 46-year-old businesswoman who has multiple activities but manages to divide her time wisely.  She lives in Bagong Silang, Caloocan City.  Her husband Prudencio, 49, is an employee. They have two children, the eldest is in college and the other is in high school.

Anita is into direct selling of cosmetics.  Like most Filipina women entrepreneurs, she gets rebates from items that she gets from reputable cosmetics and apparel companies on consignment (Avon, Sarah Lee, Board Walk, Natasha, etc.) and sells them to customers on an installment basis.  She also makes rags from fabric trimmings and sells them to customers.  She also repacks and retails powder detergent.  She is also selling electronic load credits for mobile phones.  These combined activities give Anita a sure net income of at least P16,000.00 a month.

She joined the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in 2005.  She has learned from the cooperative the value of saving for the future.  She used her savings for the renovation of their house.  She wishes to see all her children finish their education.

Anita has applied for a new loan with the cooperative amounting to P50,000.00 as additional capital to keep her businesses going.  



About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice.  This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context.  It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.  

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: As additional capital to keep her businesses going

loans.name: New Era Group

texts.en:
Siah N. and her fellow group members are from the Foyah Market area in the Foyah District of Lofa County. Siah lives with her two children, ages three and 14. Her older child is in ninth grade.

Siah sells items such as salt, onions, cubes, and manpo at market. She has done this for about three years now, and her business allows her to support her children and pay their school fees. Her primary challenge has been the lack of finances, but she is successful in attracting her customers by providing for their needs with reasonable and affordable prices.

She dreams of a bigger business so as to adequately support her kids.

loans.use: To buy additional goods such as salt, onions, cubes, and manpo to sell at market

loans.name: Emelia

texts.en:
“Never get tired in life, work patiently so that someday life will work comfortably with you”, says Emelia. It was a saying once shared to her by her mother before. That saying has served as a reminder to her when her fate in life seems unfair. Lorna is now 41 years old. She has already one child. She is married to Efren who is now 46 years old. He is a farmer in their village at Barangay Sta. Isabel Norte Ilagan, Isabela. 

Their child Emildred, is already a graduating high school student. The couple is hoping to send her in college after graduation that is why, they both working too hard to save some of their incomes from their livelihood projects. They hope that their business will be sustained to meet the educational needs of their child.

Emelia is working patiently to grow her general store that she had been managing for years. She is hoping to retail more goods to sell so that she will become more productive in the business. For this reason, Emelia is asking the assistance of KIVA lenders to lend her the amount of PHP5, 000 as additional business capital to buy additional goods to sell.

loans.use: Additional capital to buy more goods to sell

loans.name: Zuela

texts.en:
Zuela is thirty-five years old. She is married and has given birth to three children, all of whom are in school. She lives with her children and husband in a rented apartment in a busy commercial town called Ejura in the Ashanti region of Ghana. She works to support her husband financially to provide for the family.

Zuela is a trader. She trades in cereals such as maize, beans, groundnuts (peanuts), etc. She procures the goods from nearby communities and sells at the local market to food vendors and retailers.

Zuela has been in business for ten years and wants a loan to procure goods in bulk. She is hopeful to give her children the best education she can afford.

loans.use: To buy cereals in bulk

loans.name: Alma Rosibel

texts.es: Alma Rosibel D. A. reside en el departamento de Usulután al  oriente del país. Alma tiene 21 años de edad es madre soltera de dos niños de 8 y 3 tres años de edad. Alma recibe solo $60 US, por parte del padre de sus hijos, dinero que no le es suficiente para los gastos que representa todo el hogar, es por esta razón que hace un año y medio, a través de sus ahorros ella ha montado una tienda en su hogar, Alma esta consiente que sola no podrá, ya que no cuanta con los recursos económicos suficientes para surtir bien su tienda, ahora ella solicita de este crédito para poder comprar variedad de productos para su negocio y así obtener mayores ganancias que son de gran ayuda para los gastos que asume día a día.
texts.en:
Alma Rosibel D. A. lives in the department of Usulután, which is in the eastern part of the country. She is 21 years old and a single mother of two children, ages 8 and 3. Alma receives only $60 USD from the father of her children, but this is not enough to cover the expenses for her entire household. For this reason, she used her savings to open a store out of her home and has now been in business for 1½ years.

Alma is aware that she does not have the financial resources to keep her store well-stocked. For this reason, she is requesting a loan so that she can buy a variety of products for her business. This will help her generate better earnings and provide needed assistance in meeting her daily expenses.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase additional inventory for her store

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose G. is currently in the business of selling charcoal in the market and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of charcoal to sell. Rose is 30 years old and is married to a peasant. She has 6 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build up a charcoal store.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights, and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 female members.

loans.use: To stock more bags of charcoal to sell.

loans.name: Jorge Alberto

texts.es: Jorge Alberto E. M. de 27 años de edad, reside en Colón en el departamento de La Libertad, vive junto a su esposa y sus tres hijos, uno de 6 años y los gemelos de a penas un año de edad. Jorge tiene un microbus (nombre por el cual se le conoce a los buses pequeños en nuestro país), en el cual transporta a persona de oficinas a sus diferentes lugares de trabajo. Jorge depende únicamente de este modo de trabajo para mantener a su familia, es por esto que él solícita un préstamo por medio del cual pueda comprar los repuestos necesarios para el microbus y así mismo llevarlo a la revisión de mantenimiento del mismo. Todo esto lo hace ya que desea poder brindar un mejor servicio en el cual sus clientes puedan viajar de una manera más segura, así mismo porque se siente muy afortunado de contar con medio de transporte el cual le permite obtener las ganancias necesaria para el sostén de su familia, es por ello que para Jorge es muy importante cuidar la fuente de trabajo que posee.
texts.en:
Jorge Alberto E. M. is 27 years old. He lives in Colón, in the department of La Libertad. He lives with his wife and their three children, a six-year old and twins that are barely a year old. Jorge has a microbus business (the name that small busses are called in his country), in which he brings people to offices and different workplaces. Jorge depends solely on this work to support his family, for which he requests a loan so that he can pay for the necessary repairs for the microbus and also bring it in for a tune-up. In this way, he can offer better service to his customers so that they can travel in a more secure manner. Also, he feels very fortunate to have his own means of transport that allows him to obtain earnings necessary for his family’s sustenance. For this reason, Jorge feels it very important to care for the source of his work.

Translated from Spanish by Rebecca Towle, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To pay for repairs and maintenance

loans.name: Mirian Concepción

texts.es: Mirian Concepción A. D. T. D. 51 años D. edad resiD. en Jiquilisco, departamento D. Usulután. Vive junto a sus cuatro hijos menores D. edad, los cuales se dedican a estudiar. Ella posee una tortillería en su propia casa, lugar al cual las personas llegan a comprar las tortillas, así mismo sus hijos le ayudan a repartirlas D. casa en casa a las personas que hacen los encargos. Ella solícita un préstamo para poder comprar maíz para la elaboración D. tortillas, esto debido a que cuenta con una gran demanda y muchas veces no pueD. atenderla toda debido a que se queda sin la masa, la cual esta hecha a base D. maíz. Mirian cuenta con 20 años D. realizar el mismo trabajo, el cual lo aprecia mucho ya que es gracias a este que ella logra darles una vida mejor a sus hijos, por ello ella desea seguir adelante con la tortillería, ya que es madre soltera y debe trabajar por cuatro hijo los cuales depenD. únicamente D. ella.
texts.en:
Mirian Concepción A. D. T. is 51 years old. She lives in Jiquilisco, in the Usulután region. Her four young children are all in school. Mirian has a tortilla stand in her home. People stop by to purchase tortillas, but her children also help distribute orders to other houses. Mirian will use her loan to buy corn, which she uses to make tortillas. She gets plenty of orders, but sometimes she runs out of dough. Mirian has been in this line of work for 20 years, and she greatly appreciates this loan. It will allow her to give her children a better life. She needs to continue operating her tortilla stand because she is a single mother and her four children are completely dependent on her.

Translated from Spanish by Corinne Gilroy, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying corn

loans.name: Isidoro

texts.es: Don Isidoro es un padre de familia muy dedicado a su familia, casado y con cinco hijos que su esposa dio, de los cuales solo dos estudian ya que los otros ya se casaron, el señor Isidoro  tiene un taxi que es su fuente de trabajo desde hace quince años, cuando inicio lo hizo con un taller de mecánica, pero luego nace la idea de comprar el carro el cual, día a día recorre la capital de Managua ofreciendo su servicio de taxi, el cual en los últimos meses están malas las carrera debido a la alza del combustible ya que los clientes a veces no quieren pagar la carrera cara. A si como hay día muy buenos. Su esposa vende fritanga por las noches para mejorar los ingresos y poder cubrir los gastos del agua y luz. Con este préstamo quiere comprar materiales de construcción como: cerámica, zinc y perlines para construir la cocina y poder gozar de las mejoras y esfuerzos de trabajo. Sus mejores deseos es poder cambiar de unidad de taxi para poder atraer más clientes.
texts.en:
Mr. Isidoro is a father very dedicated to his family. He is married with five children, of whom only two are in school studying as the other ones have already married. Mr. Isidoro has a taxi, which has been his source of income for the past fifteen years. When he started to work he worked in a mechanic shop, but then he got the idea to buy a car. Every day, he drives around the capital of Managua offering taxi services. For the past few months, business has not been going well because the rise in gas prices has made some customers unwilling to pay the increased trip costs. But there are still very good days. Mr. Isidoro's wife sells fried food at night to increase the income and allow them to cover the household costs of water and electricity. With this loan, the couple wants to buy construction materials like ceramic, zinc, and metal beams to build a kitchen so they are able to enjoy the benefits and efforts of the wife's work. The couple's biggest desire is to be able to change the unit of the taxi so they can attract more clients.

Translated from Spanish by Lydia Brantley, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying construction materials to build a kitchen

loans.name: Jess

texts.en: 40-year-old Jess recently joined CEVI and he is thankful to have gained access to its financial service. He said that his farm could now be properly funded. He is married to Julita and they have four children. Their oldest child is now 15 years old and goes to school. Jess works hard to give his children a proper education. He requested Php 6,000 from CEVI, which he will use to purchase seeds, fertilizer and other necessary farm inputs needed at his farm. He hopes that this loan will make his farm more productive.

loans.use: Farm Supplies

loans.name: Roth

texts.en:
Roth T. is a 49 year-old widow and resides with her six children in Phnom Penh City, Cambodia. She sells breakfast near the railroad in her village, earning an income of approximately $3 per day. Four of her children are employed at a local garment factory, earning $2 per day each and helping to cover the family expenses. The family's standard of living has improved since T. started her businesses, so she wants a loan to expand it.

T. is requesting a loan of $200 to buy one more table and some chairs to serve her new and existing customers. This is her fifth loan from CREDIT, partnered with Kiva.

loans.use: To buy one more table and some chairs.

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John W. is 62 years old. He sells bricks, a business he started in 2003 in Manyole, Nambale, Busia District, where he also lives with his wife and eight children.
Before John started this business, he used to be a farmer but farming could not provide him with enough funds to facilitate his children’s education. But with his brick business, things have changed. Now John wants to further expand the business so that one day he will have enough money to buy a plot of land and build rental houses. He is requesting a loan of 20,000 KES.

loans.use: To improve his business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Sell millet-meal mush

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en:
Cecilia C. is a 63-year-old woman living in the town of Hacienda Inang, Barangay San Pablo, Manapla, Negros Occidental. She is married and has seven adult children. Cecilia owns and operates a fishing business, harvesting fish from pens she constructed along the shoreline and selling fish in the local community. She has been engaged in this business for over forty years and earns approximately PHP 15,000 a month.

In 2004, Cecilia joined NWTF to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of PHP 28,000 from NWTF.

Cecilia is now requesting a new loan of PHP 28,000 which will be used to purchase additional fish fry to raise in her fish pens. This loan will be her 13th from NWTF. Cecilia plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

 About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To purchase additional fish to raise and sell

loans.name: Thelma

texts.en:
Thelma A. is a 50-year-old married woman who supports her family by engaging in her general store and tricycle business. She lives in Barangay Daan Banwa, Kabankalan City, Negros Occidental with her 46-year-old husband, Eusebio, who drives their own tricycle.  They have 3 adult children who are between 16-26 years old.

Thelma has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 1998 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her general store and tricycle business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of $140.

She is now borrowing 15,000 PHP for the operations of her general store and tricycle business. This will be her 16th cycle loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of 25,000 PHP, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Thelma aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the “Dungganon” way.  

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additonal working capital

loans.name: Ayyub

texts.en:
Ayyub Q. is a 58-year-old man who is engaged in livestock breeding. He sells cattle for meat production to local butcher shops and restaurants. He started this business right after school. He is married and has four children who actively help to run his business.

Ayyub’s job is very hard as he spends all his day outside, grazing his cattle and looking after them. With his first loan from AqroInvest he was able to increase the number of his cows and improve his life conditions. At the same time he recommended himself as a client with a successful client history.

Now Ayyub has applied for a 1,000 AZN loan to purchase three cattle and fodder.

loans.use: To purchase three calves and fodder

loans.name: Nicodemus

texts.en:
Nicodemus is 33 years old, married and has six children, all attending school, between the ages of 4 and 14 years old. A farmer from Kisii town in Western Kenya, Nicodemus has been practising mixed farming for over 10 years. He sells his main produce of sugarcane, bananas, tea and milk to the local market and Kenya Tea Development Authority. His main challenges in farming are insufficient capital and poor market prices.

Nicodemus is requesting this loan from Juhudi Kilimo for KES.45,000 to purchase and insure a dairy cow. The extra income arising from this loan will help him pay the school fees for his children and start a small business. In the future he would like to acquire three more dairy cows to improve his production and sale of milk.

He is grateful to Juhudi for its support.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Ndioro

texts.fr: Ndioro D. est âgée de 41 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 04 enfants. Elle est membre du Banc Villageois de SAMBA 15 ANS2 depuis le 05 aout 2003 et a 13 fois de suite reçu de crédit. Elle fait un petit commerce d’huile de palme et fait aussi la transformation et vente de pâte d’arachide. Elle a une bonne expérience en la matière pour l’avoir pratiquée depuis plus de 5 ans et l’objet de son crédit est de renforcer son activité. Son objectif est de contribuer à la prise en charge familiale tout en augmentant ses épargnes.
texts.en:
Ndioro D. is 41 years old. She is married and the mother of four children. She has been a member of the “Banc Villageois” Samba 15ANS2 since August 5, 2003 and has received 13 consecutive loans. She has a small retail business where she sells palm oil but also processes and sells peanut butter. She masters this trade having practiced it for over five years. The reason for her loan is to strengthen her activity. Her goal is to participate in providing for the family’s expenses while increasing her savings.

Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To promote her commercial activities

loans.name: Imelda

texts.en:
Mrs. Imelda Q. is from the village of P2 Malaubang, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental. She is 38 years of age and blessed with three school-aged children.  She is presently engaged in recycling scrap metals, plastics and bottles. Imelda and her husband have been engaged in this kind of business for three years and earn approximately $63 a month from sales of their junk scrap metal, plastic and bottles.

 In 2009, Imelda joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. She is now requesting a new loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used to add to her capital for their business. This will be her 2nd loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family, and also as savings for future business expansion and their children’s education.
 
 About PMPC:
 Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital for their recycling business

loans.name: Ma. Ligaya

texts.en:
This is Ma. Ligaya B., 40, a resident of Silang, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Rosendo B., a contractor. She is the mother of four children, two of whom are in high school while the other two are still in elementary schools. By the grace of God, Ligaya has managed to support her children's schooling. At this time, she is working hard to be able to send them all the way through college. This is a dream for most Filipino parents like Ligaya as she herself is college graduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents can leave to their children.

Ma. Ligaya operates a junk shop and a retail store. She is also a fruit dealer, buying fruit wholesale and retailing it in the market. Trash is not actively segregated in the Philippines and, while waiting for their local dump trucks, people scavenge garbage dumps and trash bags for recyclable materials like metal, copper, plastic and paper. They sell these to junk shops like Juanita’s for a little profit. Junk shops then stack, clean and gather huge quantities of these materials and sell them back to foundries like factories. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of Php200, 300, and 350 in sales every day in the junk shop, retail store and fruit vending business respectively.

To help her continue operating her business, she is requesting a Php48,000 loan. She will be incorporating the loan into her current revolving fund used to buy trash from collectors. She also will also invest a portion of the loan to buy groceries for her store and wholesale fruits to be incorporated into her current product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 
 
Ligaya dreams of being able to give her all her children a good, high quality education through her hard work in her business.

loans.use: to add to her cash reserves used buy trash from collectors; to buy groceries and wholesale fruits for resale

loans.name: Konoweka Womens Group-Kayunga

texts.en:
For the last six years, 46-year-old, good-humored and affable Bonny N. has been enjoying good spells of financial success running her cereals and fresh fruits business in Kyamumbi-Kayunga. She has been working vigorously to establish a strong foothold for herself in the local market over these years, given the competitive nature of her kind of business. 

Bonny has not stopped short of any measures aimed at enhancing her business prospects. She took root with savings from her farming business. In a week, her profits add up to 25,000 shillings. 

Bonny, a married mother of six, also operates a school. 

With this loan, she wants to buy more bags of  cereals and fruits that she will be able to sell on a large scale.

loans.use: The purchase of more bags of cereals and fresh fruits for resale

loans.name: Stella

texts.en:
Stella T. is currently in the business of selling green vegetables, fish and fruits such as guava and oranges. She is requesting a loan to stock more fish to sell.  

Stella is 47 years old and married to a builder. She has five children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: Stock more fish to sell

loans.name: Maame

texts.en:
Maame F. is married and has four children. Maame sells sugar cane at Takoradi. Her husband is a poultry farmer. She has received junior high education. Maame uses her income to help her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills.

 Maame will use the loan to purchase more sugar cane for sale. With the new earnings from her extended business, she plans on plowing her profit back into her business.

loans.use: purchase more of her goods for sale

loans.name: Burulai's Group

texts.en:
According to the historical facts, Kyrgyzstan was known as the land of nomads. The main occupations of the Kyrgyz people were cattle breeding and farming. Since that time, many things have been changed. Now it is the country of contrasts: contrasts between richness and poverty. In the cities people work in modern offices, but in small villages people have to lead their ancestors’ mode of life.

Burulai K. is the leader of the group. She is 52, a widow. At the present moment she has a job as the cook in the Tashkumyr professional lycee (secondary school). Twenty years ago, by personal initiative, she bought three goats, and during the years she has managed to obtain a “Niva” car. Burulai wants to get a loan to buy more goats for breeding. One of the most important aims for Burulai is to buy a new car.

Abdipatta J., 42, together with his wife, who works as a cook, is raising four daughters. His business started five years ago with cattle breeding. Besides running his business, he works as an electrician in Jalalabat. During his working years has managed to buy a foreign car. The purpose of his loan is to create household buildings.

Talantbek O., 26, is married and has two infant children. Two years ago his wife’s parents incited him to start his own business by presenting him with a cow. Besides his business he has a current job as an electrician in Jalalabat. He has been making a profit, and has managed to buy necessary domestic appliances. The purpose of his loan is to buy livestock for further breeding. Talantbek is planning to buy a house with modern conveniences.

Sabirahan J., 61, is a widow. She earns her livelihood by working as a watchman in a professional lycee. Besides her job, she breeds cattle. Planning for the future, Sabirahan wants to build a bath-house, garage and other necessary outbuildings.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our lending team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase goats for breeding

loans.name: San Juan Group

texts.es:
El comité se Denomina “San Juan“están en el Séptimo Ciclo   con 15  integrantes,  es un grupo que se destaca  en el barrio por ser muy unidas solidarias  y responsable entre ellas, las mismas poseen  ahorro  y trabajan en conjunto para la recaudación de fondos para el Grupo.
La Sra. María Graciela se dedica a la venta de ropas, zapatos, zapatillas, para damas, caballeros y niños, con diferentes precios de acuerdo a la marca del producto. El negocio le resulta bastante beneficioso, teniendo en cuenta los años dedicados al mismo y a la buena clientela que posee.
Desea incrementar sus ingresos, comprando al por mayor y más variedad de ropas, teniendo en cuenta la llegada de la primavera, razón por la cual la demanda aumenta, principalmente en prendas más cómodas y frescas.
Invertirá en adquirir al por mayor las mercaderías, abaratando así los precios de costo y redundando en mayores ingresos para seguir creciendo en el ramo.
texts.en:
The committee is called “San Juan” (St. John). It is in its 7th cycle with 15 members. It is a group that is notable in the neighborhood for being very unified, mutually supportive and responsible among themselves. They have savings and work together to raise funds for the group. María Graciela sells clothes, shoes and sandals for women, men and children at different prices according to the brand of the product. The business is quite beneficial taking into account the years she has dedicated to it and the good customer base she has. She wants to increase income buying at wholesale a larger variety of clothes keeping in mind the approach of spring when demand increases especially in comfortable, cool clothing. She will invest to get items at wholesale thereby decreasing her costs that will lead to larger profits so that she can continue to grow in the field.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy seasonal clothes at wholesale for later resale at retail.

loans.name: Erdenebayar

texts.en: Mr.Erdenebayar is 23 years old and lives with his wife and son, who attends a local kindergarten. Erdenebayar’s wife is a kitchen assistant at Baylag Dinery. They don’t have their own place to live at the moment. They are living in his wife’s aunt’s place in a ger (a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent) in Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. Mr.Erdenebayar runs an on-call computer repair service, 1 hour photo service and printing service. He started this business with two of his friends, 2 years ago. He has gained a lot of experience since then. He is a very energetic, inventive person. He started this business with two printers, two digital cameras and two computers. He is planning to purchase a ger for his family. This is his second loan from this MFI and he has a good repayment history. He is requesting a loan of 500,000 tugriks to extend his business by setting up a new stall for selling different computer hardware and gadgets.

loans.use: To set up a new stall for selling different computer hardware and gadgets

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Rebecca N. lives in the Busega neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has 5 children, all of whom are in school. She also takes care of an additional family member (adopted child).

Rebecca has a business of selling milk. She has been in this business for 1 year, and she works 7 days out of every week. Rebecca sells her products door-to-door, by means of retail. Rebecca has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more jerrycans of milk. She also generates additional income through a food stall. The main business challenges for Rebecca include transportation and the rainy season which hinders her movements. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to start selling wholesale and also to get a permanent business premise.

Rebecca lives in a home that she owns; she doesn't have access to electricity and doesn't have access to piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees and feeding the family.

loans.use: To buy more jerrycans of milk.

loans.name: Carlos Julio

texts.es:
En la ciudadela La California de  Portoviejo, capital de Manabí conocida desde hace muchos años  como la ciudad de los reales tamarindos, se reúnen cada quince días  las socias del Banco Comunal Rio De Oro.

En este lugar encontramos a Carlos Julio, tiene 22 años y está soltero, el es de la provincia del guayas pero hace algunos años se vino para Portoviejo, ahora el vive en la casa de su hermana.

Desde muy joven él se dedico a trabajar en albañilería y ahora a su edad es ya un maestro albañil, dice que los Ing. Civiles que lo conocen le dan sus obras para que él se las construya y el cómo sabe su trabajo con mucho gusto acepta ya que trabajo es lo que necesita para salir adelante, además con el trabajan tres personas mas a los cuales les paga por semana, pero para realizar su trabajo el necesita de herramientas que le permitan realizar su labor.

Es por eso que solicito este nuevo crédito para comprar mas herramientas de trabajo, con este crédito piensa comprar dos carretillas, cuatro lampas, y una cortadora de hierro. Este es el tercer ciclo en el Banco Comunal y está muy agradecido porque gracias a los crédito ha podido comprar sus herramientas que le han permitido conseguir mas trabajos. Su sueño es tener su propia empresa de construcción.
texts.en:
In the town of La California de Portoviejo, capital of Manabí and known for many years as the city of the regal tamarind, the members of the Rio de Oro cooperative bank reunite every fifteen days.

This is where we find Carlos Julio, who is 22 years old and single.  He is originally from the Guayas province, but came to Portoviejo several years ago, and now lives in his sister’s house.

From a young age, he dedicated himself to working in construction.  Now, at this age, he is a master builder, and says that the civil engineers that know him seek him out to give him work.  Because he knows his trade so well, he gladly accepts, since work is what he needs to get ahead.  In addition, he works with three other people who he pays on a weekly basis.  To do his work well, he needs some more tools.

He is requesting this new loan in order to purchase more tools for his trade.  He is thinking about using the funds to buy two wheelbarrows, four spades, and one wire cutter.  This is his third cycle with the cooperative bank, and he is very grateful because thanks to the credit he has been able to buy tools that allowed him to obtain more jobs.  His dream is to have his own construction company.

loans.use: To purchase two wheelbarrows, four spades and one wire cutter.

loans.name: Justo

texts.es: Justo, de 52 años, convive con Domitila, de 46 años. Ambos tuvieron 2 hijos: Roxana, de 21 y Viviana, de 17 años. En unión familiar ellos viven en una casa alquila, ubicada en la localidad de San Pedro de Cajas. Este hombre hábil y emprendedor; trabajaba en una tienda de venta de combustibles, labor que le generaba un dinero extra a su oficio de artesano que desde los 18 años hasta hoy practica. Hoy posee su propio taller, siendo sus principales tejidos: ponchos y mantas; los que gracias a su dedicación y creatividad, le generan grandes pedidos de compradores de las diferentes ciudades del país, los que constantemente visitan su taller, para poder comprarlos. Sus buenas ganancias, le permitieron ahorrar y hace tan solo tres años, abrió su propio “grifo”, ahí suministra gasolina a los diferentes chóferes de su localidad. Ahora desea invertir más en la mejora de su negocio. Es el tercer crédito con MFP y se siente feliz del trabajo realizado en todo este tiempo, “ya aprendí a ahorrar y proyectarme”, afirma. Con el crédito que obtendrá, le ayudará a invertir en la compra de combustibles, donde cada cilindro cuesta un promedio de S/. 620.00 nuevos soles y si el dinero le alcanza invertirá también en la compra de hilos y demás insumos para la elaboración de sus tejidos.
texts.en:
